qas.question: When did New Zealand's Supreme Court come into being?
What is the role of New Zealand's highest court?
What court's decisions may be appealed to New Zealand's supreme court?

answers.text: Court of Appeal of New Zealand

qas.question: New Zealand's second ranking court is known as what?
Local decisions by what judicial body may remain within the jurisdiction of local courts?

plausible_answers.text: new Supreme Court of New Zealand

qas.question: What was officially established at the beginning of 1980?

plausible_answers.text: The High Court of New Zealand

qas.question: What was the Supreme Court known as until 2004?
Where are appeals always moved to from the High Court?
What are the District Court and Court of Appeal considered to be?

context: The <b5_0>new Supreme Court of New Zealand<b5_0/> was officially established at the beginning of <a0_0>2004<a0_0/>, although it did not come into operation until July. <b6_0>The High Court of New Zealand<b6_0/> was until 1980 known as the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court has a <a1_0>purely appellate<a1_0/> jurisdiction and hears appeals from the <a2_0>Court of Appeal of New Zealand<a2_0/>. In some cases, an appeal may be removed directly to the <b7_0>Supreme Court<b7_0/> from the High Court. For certain cases, particularly cases which commenced in <a4_0>the District Court<a4_0/>, a <b8_0>lower court<b8_0/> (typically <a3_0>the High Court<a3_0/> or the Court of Appeal) may be the court of final jurisdiction.
